item.title: Comment on Nathan Marsak by Eric Boardman
item.dc:creator: Eric Boardman
item.description:
Nathan,
Eager to hear your talk on October 5. Thank you for keeping the history alive.
item.content:encoded:
Nathan,

Eager to hear your talk on October 5. Thank you for keeping the history alive.

item.title: Comment on A day trip to 19th Century Los Angeles by Lewis G.
item.dc:creator: Lewis G.
item.description: Hi Gordon, I'm finding the history of Bunker Hill so intriguing. You mention the city's skyline, and that got me wondering, do you remember if the beautiful Eastern Columbia Building was visible from Bunker Hill when you were living there? Maybe from atop Angel's Flight or the lookout tower above that? Thanks!
item.content:encoded: Hi Gordon, I’m finding the history of Bunker Hill so intriguing. You mention the city’s skyline, and that got me wondering, do you remember if the beautiful Eastern Columbia Building was visible from Bunker Hill when you were living there? Maybe from atop Angel’s Flight or the lookout tower above that? Thanks!

item.title: Comment on The Castle – 325 S. Bunker Hill Avenue by jean karwelis
item.dc:creator: jean karwelis
item.content:encoded:
for the Castle dweller, i would love to talk to you about this home and recreating some drawing for floor plans so i can build a scale model of the castle. eventually i think i would donate all to the heritage square museum

 

my email is keoni121@aim.com

or call me 775-455-7986

item.title: Comment on Welcome to My Bunker Hill by Alexis Shoemaker
item.dc:creator: Alexis Shoemaker
item.content:encoded:
A friend of mine sent me pictures of Old Los Angeles over 10 years ago, because he knew that I was born in Los Angeles. Â One picture stoped me in my tracks, and It was “The Castle”! Â I could swear I had seen it some where before and I can’t put my finger on it. Â  I have been obsessed with trying to find out who the original architect wasÂ for the floor plan lay-out was before the add-ons. Â Would you have any idea of who it is? Or who they are?

Old Los Angeles has been my muse for all my art projects while I attended the local college.

item.title: Comment on An Evening at Angels Flight by Christine Hennessy
item.dc:creator: Christine Hennessy
item.description:
hello,
My Â great grandmother Bridget Ohara Fitzgerald, at one point in time ran the Touraine Apartments, Or she owned it. (I am not sure.) I cannot find any history of this, and wonder if you can help me. I would be very greatful. She died June 9th, 1948 in Los Angeles, on Green St. in those Apartments she owned.
 
Thank you,
Christine Hennessy
item.content:encoded:
hello,

My Â great grandmother Bridget Ohara Fitzgerald, at one point in time ran the Touraine Apartments, Or she owned it. (I am not sure.) I cannot find any history of this, and wonder if you can help me. I would be very greatful. She died June 9th, 1948 in Los Angeles, on Green St. in those Apartments she owned.

 

Thank you,

Christine Hennessy

item.title: Comment on The Larronde Residence – 237 N. Hope Street by Steve Sichi
item.dc:creator: Steve Sichi
item.description: Very interesting! Â Didnâ€t know anything about the Larronde family. Â I just found my great grandfather Floyd Desseryâ€s Los Angeles High School Spanish textbook. There is a sticker in the front naming John M. Larronde, 237 Hope Street. I am assuming John sold/passed it to my great grandfather, who graduated from LA High in 1898. The Desserys were also French immigrants who lived in Brooklyn Heights (now Boyle Heights.)
item.content:encoded: Very interesting! Â Didnâ€™t know anything about the Larronde family. Â I just found my great grandfather Floyd Desseryâ€™s Los Angeles High School Spanish textbook. There is a sticker in the front naming John M. Larronde, 237 Hope Street. I am assuming John sold/passed it to my great grandfather, who graduated from LA High in 1898. The Desserys were also French immigrants who lived in Brooklyn Heights (now Boyle Heights.)

item.title: Comment on Rose Mansion – 400 South Grand Avenue by Brian Alan Baaker
item.dc:creator: Brian Alan Baaker
item.description: <p>Good introduction to an extraordinary citrus grower. “Sunny Slope” appears as a city (with its own rail stop) on maps from the last quarter of the 19th century.</p> <p> </p>
item.content:encoded: Good introduction to an extraordinary citrus grower. “Sunny Slope” appears as a city (with its own rail stop) on maps from the last quarter of the 19th century.

item.title: Comment on The Hotel Elmar â€” 235 South Hope St. by Patricia Yonemoto
item.dc:creator: Patricia Yonemoto
item.description:
In reply to <a href="https://www.onbunkerhill.org/theelmar/#comment-31582">Chelsea</a>.
I could very well be your great aunt, but one must be careful who they contact on the internet.Â There are three things about the birth of my brother's daughter that only our families would know.Â The first being her mother's first name.Â If you know these three things, then I am your great aunt, and we should meet.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Chelsea.

I could very well be your great aunt, but one must be careful who they contact on the internet.Â  There are three things about the birth of my brother’s daughter that only our families would know.Â  The first being her mother’s first name.Â  If you know these three things, then I am your great aunt, and we should meet.

item.title: Comment on The Hotel Elmar â€” 235 South Hope St. by Chelsea
item.dc:creator: Chelsea
item.description:
In reply to <a href="https://www.onbunkerhill.org/theelmar/#comment-13999">Patricia Yonemoto</a>.
My mother was born Deborah Darlene Mitchell. Her dad was Ernest Owens Chilson, son of Adah and Thearn Chilson. Is this your brother? My mother didn't really know her dad or much of his family, but I think we might be related. I hope your book is working out well. Please get back to me as you might be my mother's aunt and my great aunt.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Patricia Yonemoto.

My mother was born Deborah Darlene Mitchell. Her dad was Ernest Owens Chilson, son of Adah and Thearn Chilson. Is this your brother? My mother didn’t really know her dad or much of his family, but I think we might be related. I hope your book is working out well. Please get back to me as you might be my mother’s aunt and my great aunt.

item.title: Comment on The Castle – 325 S. Bunker Hill Avenue by Susan
item.dc:creator: Susan
item.description: Does anyone have pictures of North Flower Street? I'm searching for anything taken on the 200 NorthÂ block to put in a family history.Â I know these were large frame buildings, but I've been unable to find them on the internet.Â I'm also searching for a map showing Flower Street up on the Hill.Â Every map I've found is so hard to use that it's useless.
item.content:encoded: Does anyone have pictures of North Flower Street? I’m searching for anything taken on the 200 NorthÂ  block to put in a family history.Â  I know these were large frame buildings, but I’ve been unable to find them on the internet.Â  I’m also searching for a map showing Flower Street up on the Hill.Â  Every map I’ve found is so hard to use that it’s useless.
